thread.title: Corruption Currents: U.S. Official Warns Banks Against Dealing With Blacklisted Russians

author: Samuel Rubenfeld
title: Corruption Currents: U.S. Official Warns Banks Against Dealing With Blacklisted Russians
text:
0 COMMENTS Sigal Mandelker, U.S. Treasury undersecretary for terrorism and financial intelligence, center, speaks last month at the Department of Justice in Washington, D.C.. Photo: Bloomberg News
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories vi a our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
Former Israeli premier Ehud Olmert, who served a 16-month sentence for bribery, requested a pardon. Separately, more than a dozen officials were arrested . (JTA, TOI)
U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions turned to a man convicted in a 2009 bribery case for advice on who to nominate for federal prosecutor positions. (ProPublica)
Local cases: A Long Island corruption trial continues . The retrials of former New York State legislative leaders are set to begin . (Newsday, LowDown, WSJ)
Cybercrime:
Criminals targeted Arizona’s voting systems. (Reuters)
Money Laundering;
Virtually every dollar associated with Backpage.com was derived from illicit activity, prosecutors asserted in a 93-count indictment alleging money laundering and prostitution. The lawyer for one defendant didn’t reply to requests for comment; another couldn’t be identified. (Verge, Engadget, CNN, AP)
U.K. authorities haven’t made any arrests in the month since the U.S. filed charges that led to the closure of a brokerage. Separately, a white paper examines the holes in the U.K. anti-money-laundering system. (Times, RUSI)
A temple under construction in India allegedly was used by an influential South African family to launder money. (News24)
Russia demanded the U.K. repatriate $8 billion in assets seized in financial crimes. (MT)
Australian authorities stuck to their allegations a bank breached money-laundering rules. (CT)
A judge again denied bail for Paul Manafort, the former Trump presidential campaign chair. (ProPublica)
Pakistani authorities are working on banning terror groups. (Tribune, GEO, DT, PTI)
South Korean regulators plan to inspect three banks over anti-money laundering compliance. (Yonhap, Menafn, CD)
A cryptocurrency exchange was implicated in a money-laundering scandal in Poland. It didn’t immediately comment. Europe busted a crime ring using credit cards and cryptocurrency to launder funds. (CCN, DPA)
The U.S. said a number of Caribbean countries launder drug proceeds. (JO, BBN)
Psychological help in prison for a money launderer turned her life around. (SCMP)
An American pleaded guilty to money laundering in Singapore. (YH, ST)
Indian authorities continue their efforts against money laundering. (LM, PTI, AA)
Sanctions:
Banks that deal with blacklisted Russians will face consequences , a top U.S. Treasury official said. Russia is drawing up plans to retaliate against the latest sanctions . Could sanctions harm Russia’s fragile economy? There’s no doubt about it, one official said. (MT, Bloomberg, AP, Reuters, Meduzia, Reuters, MT)
Rusal told customers not to pay the $396 million in debt they owe while it figures out how to address sanctions. Industry insiders say Rio Tinto PLC will benefit and U.S. consumers will lose. One oligarch lost $1.1 billion in a day; the 50 richest Russians lost $12 billion. (Bloomberg, Reuters, Bloomberg, MT)
U.S. sanctions on Russia hit Swiss companies. (SwissInfo)
Iran told U.S. President Donald Trump he’ll regret it if he exits the nuclear deal. Iran’s currency hit all-time lows due in part to sanctions. The country unified its exchange rates. (Reuters, RFE/RL, AP, Reuters)
The U.S. delayed the sentencing of a Turkish banker convicted of violating Iran sanctions. (Reuters)
Hezbollah operations in Colombia were revealed here . (Ynet)
A review of a recent book about sanctions is here . (WOTR)
Whistleblowers:
The journalist who published the Panama Papers explains how vital tipsters were. (LAT)
The FBI uses FOIA to track down whistleblowers. (WP)
General Anti-Corruption:
The Trump Organization asked the Panamanian president to intervene in a dispute over control of a luxury hotel. (AP)
Mauritius suspended the business and froze the assets of a firm linked to an Angolan sovereign wealth fund. It comes as Angola secured $500 million frozen in an HSBC Holdings PLC account it said was embezzled by the son of the former leader. (Reuters, Bloomberg, Bloomberg)
Legal experts suggested designs for the Australian anti-graft commission. (Guardian)
A FIFA vice president quit after an audit raised questions . (AFP, AP)
As the U.S. special counsel’s probe continues , no one is ready for the fallout. (NJ, McClatchy)
